dt: {bc}to cause or bring about (something) {bc}to put (something) into effect or operation {bc}{sx|effect||2}

dt.t: … the insured or depositor relies on the insurer or bank to {wi}effectuate{/wi} his wishes …

aq.auth: William M. McGovern, Jr. et al.

dt.t: … emphasizing the importance of institutions in {wi}effectuating{/wi} good works …

utxt.t: The defendant may waive {wi}effectuation{/wi} of these rights, provided the waiver is made voluntarily, knowingly and intelligently.

et: probably borrowed (with addition of {et_link|-ate:4|-ate:4}) from Middle French {it}effectuer, affectuer,{/it} borrowed from Medieval Latin {it}effectuāre,{/it} verbal derivative of Latin {it}effectus{/it} "achievement, result, {et_link|effect:1|effect:1}"
shortdef: to cause or bring about (something) : to put (something) into effect or operation : effect
